DataElement.preferredName: Partial Breast Radiation Therapy Administration Method Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text name for a partial breast irradiation modality/method used to deliver irradiation.

Concepts.definition: Being or affecting only a part of something.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Partial Breast Carcinoma Radiation Therapy Method Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Partial; being or affecting only a part; not total_A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002_Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of external beam radiation therapy using a beam of protons. It has the advantage of precisely localizing the radiation dose on the targeted tissue and avoiding damage to the healthy surrounding tissues.

Concepts.definition: A type of external beam radiation therapy using a beam of protons. It has the advantage of precisely localizing the radiation dose on the targeted tissue and avoiding damage to the healthy surrounding tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An advanced form of 3-Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy (3D CRT) that involves the use of varying intensities of small radiation beams to produce dosage distributions that are more precise than those possible with 3D CRT.

Concepts.definition: An advanced form of 3-Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy (3D CRT) that involves the use of varying intensities of small radiation beams to produce dosage distributions that are more precise than those possible with 3D CRT.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A process by which a dose of radiation is automatically shaped to closely conform to the entire volume of the tumor, so that surrounding normal tissue is spared and treatment toxicity is decreased.

Concepts.definition: A process by which a dose of radiation is automatically shaped to closely conform to the entire volume of the tumor, so that surrounding normal tissue is spared and treatment toxicity is decreased.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Occurring during the course of a surgical procedure.

Concepts.definition: Occurring during the course of a surgical procedure.

PermissibleValues.value: Intracavitary Brachytherapy Device (MammoSite, Contour, ClearPath, etc.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Within a cavity or space, such as the abdomen, pelvis, or chest.: (ray-dee-AY-shun) A procedure in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into or near a tumor. Also called brachytherapy, internal radiation, or interstitial radiation.: An object contrived for a specific purpose.

Concepts.definition: Within a cavity or space, such as the abdomen, pelvis, or chest.
A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material is placed inside the body, into a tumor or body cavity.
An object contrived for a specific purpose.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of internal radiation therapy in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into a tumor or body tissue. (Cancer.gov): (ray-dee-AY-shun) A procedure in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into or near a tumor. Also called brachytherapy, internal radiation, or interstitial radiation.

Concepts.definition: A type of internal radiation therapy in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into a tumor or body tissue. (Cancer.gov)
A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material is placed inside the body, into a tumor or body cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: After surgery.: Radiation therapy in which high-energy beams are delivered to the tumor from outside of the body.

Concepts.definition: Relating to or occurring during the period immediately following a surgical operation.
Radiation therapy in which high-energy beams are delivered to the tumor from outside of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: After surgery.: A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into or near a tumor.: Any physical object that is useful for prevention, diagnosis, monitoring, or treatment of disease or other conditions.

Concepts.definition: Relating to or occurring during the period immediately following a surgical operation.
A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material is placed inside the body, into a tumor or body cavity.
Any physical object that is useful for prevention, diagnosis, monitoring, or treatment of disease or other conditions.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Partial Breast Carcinoma Radiation Therapy Method Type
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Partial; being or affecting only a part; not total:A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002:Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.:A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Being or affecting only a part of something.

A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated as part of Breast Oncology Local Disease (BOLD) Initiative
